Entries.default: "Kith trespassers in the goddess' Maw?! But how...?"
"What would you have of me, puny kith?"
"I will burn your bones in offering to Magran!"
"We depart forthwith. Magran's flames shall guide us."

"You must seek to follow in your defiler god's footsteps. You will not. For I will smite you where you stand!"

Bellowing, she hefts a massive sword overhead.
"Hold, segroth! I would speak to this filthy minion of the wretched god Eothas -"
"The god in that statue bid me to meet him here. I've come to speak with him."
"I'm no friend of Eothas. He stole a piece of my soul, and I mean to get it back."
[Lie] "I have nothing to do with your god problem."
"What's it to you?"

"You must possess an unfathomable power to have kindled the interest of such a... giant."

He cants his head, broad fingers scratching at the rivets of his helm.

"Ha! You think to confront an embodied god? Then you are either powerful beyond comprehension - or as much a fool."

He cants his head, broad fingers scratching at the rivets of his helm.
"You claim this ill-timed appearance of yours to be a chance occurrence? I think not."
The first giant's grip turns white-knuckled on the hilt of her sword. Her muscles strain and the metal quivers in her hand.
With a shrug of his meaty shoulders, he steps aside.
"Eothas has consumed your warriors' very souls. But I've faced him before and am still standing."
"Eothas may be seeking revenge against you Magranites, but I've nothing to do with it."
"Your fury should burn for Eothas, not me."
"I don't want to fight you. But I must deal with Eothas, no matter the cost."
[Attack] "So it has come to this."
Shoulders taut with tension, the warrior eyes the strewn corpses of his fellow Rathun-at-arms. They lie dried like husks, siphoned of their souls.
Shoulders taut with tension, the warrior eyes the strewn corpses of his fellow Rathun-at-arms. They lie dried like husks, siphoned of their souls.
Shoulders taut with tension, the warrior eyes the strewn corpses of his fellow Rathun-at-arms. They lie dried like husks, siphoned of their souls.
He places a hand out to hold the warrior back. He studies you intently.

"Trespassers of the Maw! Let the flames lick the flesh from your bones, and oblivion will come quickly."

The warriors encircle you slowly.
"Tell me - can you stand against the defiler god?"
"We have not yet defeated the embodied god, but that does not mean we won't. The bathor is readying another assault from within the Jagged Keep as we speak."
"I worry Magran plans to erupt this volcano. If you stay, you'll die."
"How can I reach Eothas?"
"You plan to attack Eothas?"
"So many bodies. Eothas has drained you nearly dry."
"Farewell."
He hefts his meaty shoulders in a heavy shrug.
"Our duty is foremost to Magran. We guard the Maw - to its fiery end."
"All who neared the intruder god were guttered until extinguished. You think your soul could last even half so long as a Rathun's?"
"Maybe the kith's will last longer."

"First we recover the wounded and their weapons - drag them into the Jagged Keep."

He nods.
"After that, we will join the bathor and the others in a secondary assault, yes."
"It's true, the god caught us unawares. We lost many, but we are not yet defeated."
"Magran has made us for this purpose. We will see to her victory through fire and blood."

"I will permit you to scamper closer to god's face, if you believe you can survive. Scurry deeper into the Maw. 

"But know that my brethren may squash you."
"A lone kith trespasses in the goddess' Maw?! But how...?"
"- before you char his bones to dust."
Entries.female: "- before you char her bones to dust."

Entries.default: "You know... the kith can hear you."
"I come on Magran's business."
"The goddess sends you... to aid us?" He scoffs, unconvinced. But when you return a defiant glare, he tilts his head, considering.
"Indeed, you stand strong when our best have withered like wood eaten to embers. Perhaps you possess great power despite your minuscule frame."
"So you freely admit you do his bidding. Yet why would a god have need of you, puny kith? To spy? To see in the places he cannot?!"
This time he whacks her hard on the back of her helmet, and cursing, she slams the flat of her sword against her shield.

"Rekir, move. We cannot allow these intruders to live!" 

Again, she thrusts the sword high.
"If you know of the war between us and the defiler god, then you must understand what has brought his foulness to our fortress."
"I hope your weapons are as keen as your wit. Both for your sake and mine, puny kith."
"I would have you stop calling me puny."
He laughs, hearty and deep, the sound like wood cracking beneath flames.
"Grow a few dozen more feet, and I will gladly oblige you."
"Only Magran's shrine within our Jagged Keep can lead you to the defiler god. Kith, if Magran wishes you to face him, surely she will fire the way."
"And then we will kill a god." Smacking the head of his staff against his chest, he bares you a garish grin.
But a second giant slams the haft of his iron staff into the warrior's hard-muscled stomach, abruptly halting her attack.
"Leave the fiery one be. I think Magran must have sent him to us."
Entries.female: "Leave the fiery one be. I think Magran must have sent her to us."

Entries.default: "Let the battle blaze!"
She snorts, but the other warrior ignores her, answering in her stead.
"Segroth, help me with the bodies. But this time gentle your grip."
"It can't be helped, rekir. These fallen are brittle."
Incensed, the giant warrior hulks. Her thick muscles twitch, red markings glowing hotly against her ashen skin.
Shoulders taut with tension, the warrior eyes the strewn corpses of his fellow Rathun-at-arms. They lie dried like husks, siphoned of their souls.
"Do not dwell on this defeat, segroth. Magran felled the defiler before. We will do so again."
"Another devoured by the foul reaper. Another deprived of the ever-flame."
"Yet you imply you do not serve him?"
"Hold, segroth! Should this kith possess knowledge of the foul god Eothas, I would learn of it -"

"You must possess an unfathomable power to have kindled the interest of such a... giant."

He cants his head, broad fingers scratching at the rivets of his helm.
"You would face us in battle rather than flee? I like your mettle, kith who does not cower before Magran's greatest warriors."
